repnme.cdata!:
Copperbelt Environment Project tackles the
            lead and uranium danger in Zambia

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about
            Copperbelt Environment Project (CEP) that tackled the lead
            and uranium danger in Zambia. In 1995, the government sold
            the mines to private investors. Although privatization
            brought many benefits to the economy, the new mine owners
            did not want to take care of the environmental liabilities
            left over by previous mines’ owners. In 2003, fifty thousand
            residents of Kabwe’s population were affected by high lead
            levels in the soil, due to naturally occurring
            mineralization as well as the impact of the smelting and
            mining operations. Although mining has been the single
            greatest contributor to economic growth in Zambia, it has
            also had significant adverse effects on the environment. Its
            effect on the environment had been largely ignored, thus
            leaving a trail of uranium, lead and other base metals whose
            by-products were not properly disposed of and administered.
            CEP determined and controlled lead blood levels in affected
            areas. It also helped to strengthen the institutional
            capacity of delegated authorizing agencies to improve future
            compliance of the mining sector with environmental and
            social regulations. The International Development
            Association (IDA) financed environmental project helped to
            clean up lead and uranium tailings from mines in Zambia and
            enabled the residents of Kabwe live in safety.

            MINING:COPPERBELT ENVIRONMENT,TF026418-PHRD-ZAMBIA: COPPERBELT
            ENVIRONMENT PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Copperbelt Environment
            Project for Zambia were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, the Bank performance was unsatisfactory, and
            the Borrower performance was moderately unsatisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: It was appropriate for the Bank to
            focus on providing financing for the remediation of
            large-scale mining-related environmental liabilities and
            obligations under the first Project. In light of the
            profitability of the mining industry, though, Bank financing
            in the case of a second Project should play more of a
            leveraging role, i.e. mobilize substantial financial
            contributions from the Government, ZCCM-IH (Zambia
            Consolidated Copper Mines Limited- Investments Holdings
            Plc), and mining companies. Under the first Project, mining
            communities in the Copperbelt Province and Kabwe did not
            adequately benefit from the thriving mining sector. To this
            day, they continue to struggle with adverse mining-related
            environmental and public health impacts, poor access to
            basic social infrastructure services, and poverty. Mining
            companies should contribute to a fund that would enable
            communities living adjacent to mines and mineral processing
            plants to be proactively involved in the design and
            implementation of small-scale community-level investments
            that would improve local living and environmental conditions
            and livelihoods. Explicit emphasis should also be placed on
            addressing gender issues. More emphasis should be placed on
            fostering social accountability: (i) 'supply side'
            governance through more access to information, in particular
            data on environmental compliance and revenues of mining
            companies; and (ii) 'demand side' governance by
            which civil society plays an active role in pollution
            monitoring and holding the Government accountable for
            enforcing environmental laws and regulations and holding
            mining companies to environmental standards.

repnme.cdata!:
Zambia - Copperbelt Environment Project :
            resettlement framework

abstracts.cdata!:
The Copperbelt Environment Project will
            address the environmental liabilities associated with the
            mining sector, following the privatization of the mining
            assets. However, in order to fully attain its objectives, of
            protecting the public health, and safety of local
            communities, prevent or reduce environmental degradation,
            and allow a productive re-use of the land, either to its
            pre-mining use, or an acceptable alternative as applicable,
            land acquisition, and therefore relocation, will occur. This
            Resettlement Action Plan sets the principles for social
            impact mitigation, as regards compensation for loss of
            property, livelihood, and resettlement related issues.
            Compensation for loss of, and access to land will be in the
            form of land for land compensation, at replacement costs to
            project affected peoples (PAPs). Economically marginalized
            PAPs, with reduced access to land, will be provided with
            land in order to enhance their living conditions. Housing
            will be provided, improved, or at least restored, with
            appropriate access to sources of water. Property assets,
            crops, and tree losses will be paid at market value
            determined by, and agreed with Government Valuation.
            Monitoring criteria, and grievance mechanisms will ensure an
            appropriate resettlement process, and resolve potential
            conflicts should they occur.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Copperbelt Environment Project in
            Zambia, will address environmental liabilities, associated
            with the mining sector, following the privatization of the
            mining assets, and, will improve future compliance of the
            mining sector with environmental, and social regulations.
            Through the environmental management facility (EMF)
            component, environmental and social problems resulting from
            the Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines Ltd. (ZCCM) operations
            prior to privatization (including the Government's
            permanent obligations), will be addressed in accordance to
            the country's environmental laws and regulations. A
            consolidated environmental management plan (CEMP) will be
            prepared, to identify priority financing, and provide the
            criteria for funding subprojects. Moreover, this CEMP will
            form the basis for managing environmental issues related to
            the Copperbelt, and Kabwe over a 25 year period, within the
            broader context of environmental, and social sustainability.
            The second component, will strengthen the environmental
            regulatory framework, by providing assistance to the
            Government, to ensure that historical, and future
            environmental liabilities arising from mining activities,
            are handled in compliance with national environmental, and
            social safeguards. To this end, capacity building will be
            supported, namely at the Environmental Council of Zambia,
            and authorizing agencies, so as to review environmental
            impacts assessments, negotiate management activities with
            investors, issue pollution permits, monitor compliance, and
            collect fees and fines. This component will also provide
            assistance to strengthen nongovernmental organizations, and
            training institutions, to increase national capacity in
            addressing environmental issues related to the mining sector.

repnme.cdata!:
Zambia - Copperbelt Environment Project :
            environmental impact assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment (EA) of
            the Copperbelt Environment Project presents an evaluation of
            mining hazards in the Copperbelt and Kabwe from a risk-based
            perspective. The primary environmental health issue in the
            Copperbelt mining sector is exposure to sulfur dioxide and
            particulate emissions in Mufulira, Kitwe, and Chambishi.
            Copper is found in excessive quantities downstream from mine
            sites. In Kabwe lead contamination in soil presents an
            immediate health concern. This EA provides the following
            recommendations: a) Clear definitions of responsibilities
            need to be set among the different institutions involved. b)
            ZCCM-IH (an investment holding company), private sector mine
            operators, and regulatory authorities will need to form a
            consensus regarding priority environmental issues to be
            addressed by their respective site-specific environmental
            management plans. c) Expenditures of the Environmental
            Mitigation Fund (EMF) should be focused towards priority
            impacts as identified in this EA. d) The various
            institutions involved have basic mandates and technical
            competency, but require an organizational focus and training
            to enable them to adequately discharge their functions. e)
            The EMF will be required to establish procedures for
            screening, implementing EA, preparing resettlement action
            plans, and consulting with affected publics and NGOs and
            disclosing safeguard documents.
